upo.graph

Interface Graph

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<Vertex>

    public interface Graph
extends java.lang.Iterable<Vertex>
    The root interface in the graph hierarchy.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static double DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT
      The default weight for an edge.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT

        static final double DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT
        The default weight for an edge.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • addVertex

        boolean addVertex(Vertex v)
        Adds the specified vertex to this graph if not already present. More formally, adds the specified vertex, v, to this graph if this graph contains no vertex u such that u.equals(v). If this graph already contains such vertex, the call leaves this graph unchanged and returns false. In combination with the restriction on constructors, this ensures that graphs never contain duplicate vertices.
        Parameters:
        v - vertex to be added to this graph.
        Returns:
        true if this graph did not already contain the specified vertex.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified vertex is null .

      • containsVertex

        boolean containsVertex(Vertex v)
        Returns true if this graph contains the specified vertex. More formally, returns true if and only if this graph contains a vertex u such that u.equals(v). If the specified vertex is null returns false.
        Parameters:
        v - vertex whose presence in this graph is to be tested.
        Returns:
        true if this graph contains the specified vertex.

      • removeVertex

        boolean removeVertex(Vertex v)
        Removes the specified vertex from this graph including all its touching edges if present. More formally, if the graph contains a vertex u such that u.equals(v), the call removes all edges that touch u and then removes u itself. If no such u is found, the call leaves the graph unchanged. Returns true if the graph contained the specified vertex. (The graph will not contain the specified vertex once the call returns).

        If the specified vertex is null returns false.

        Parameters:
        v - vertex to be removed from this graph, if present.
        Returns:
        true if the graph contained the specified vertex; false otherwise.

      • vertexSet

        java.util.Set<Vertex> vertexSet()
        Returns a set of the vertices contained in this graph.
        Returns:
        a set view of the vertices contained in this graph.

      • addEdge

        Edge addEdge(Vertex sourceVertex,
             Vertex targetVertex)
        Creates a new edge in this graph, going from the source vertex to the target vertex, and returns the created edge. Some graphs do not allow edge-multiplicity. In such cases, if the graph already contains an edge from the specified source to the specified target, than this method does not change the graph and returns null.

        The source and target vertices must already be contained in this graph. If they are not found in graph IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

        Parameters:
        sourceVertex - source vertex of the edge.
        targetVertex - target vertex of the edge.
        Returns:
        The newly created edge if added to the graph, otherwise null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if source or target vertices are not found in the graph.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the specified vertices is null.

      • containsEdge

        boolean containsEdge(Vertex sourceVertex,
                     Vertex targetVertex)
        Returns true if and only if this graph contains an edge going from the source vertex to the target vertex. If any of the specified vertices does not exist in the graph, or if is null, returns false.
        Parameters:
        sourceVertex - source vertex of the edge.
        targetVertex - target vertex of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if this graph contains the specified edge.

      • edgeSet

        java.util.Set<Edge> edgeSet()
        Returns a set of the edges contained in this graph.
        Returns:
        a set of the edges contained in this graph.

      • degreeOf

        int degreeOf(Vertex vertex)
        Returns the degree of the specified vertex.

        A degree of a vertex in an undirected graph is the number of edges touching that vertex. Edges with same source and target vertices (self-loops) are counted twice.

        In directed graphs this method returns the sum of the "in degree" and the "out degree".

        Parameters:
        vertex - vertex whose degree is to be calculated.
        Returns:
        the degree of the specified vertex.

      • inDegreeOf

        int inDegreeOf(Vertex vertex)
        Returns the "in degree" of the specified vertex.

        The "in degree" of a vertex in a directed graph is the number of inward directed edges from that vertex.

        In the case of undirected graphs this method returns the number of edges touching the vertex. Edges with same source and target vertices (self-loops) are counted twice.

        Parameters:
        vertex - vertex whose degree is to be calculated.
        Returns:
        the degree of the specified vertex.

      • outDegreeOf

        int outDegreeOf(Vertex vertex)
        Returns the "out degree" of the specified vertex.

        The "out degree" of a vertex in a directed graph is the number of outward directed edges from that vertex.

        Edges with same source and target vertices (self-loops) are counted twice.

        Parameters:
        vertex - vertex whose degree is to be calculated.
        Returns:
        the degree of the specified vertex.

      • isDirected

        boolean isDirected()
        Returns true if this is a directed graph.
        Returns:
        true if this is a directed graph, false otherwise

      • removeEdge

        Edge removeEdge(Vertex sourceVertex,
                Vertex targetVertex)
        Removes an edge going from source vertex to target vertex, if such vertices and such edge exist in this graph. Returns the edge if removed or null otherwise.
        Parameters:
        sourceVertex - source vertex of the edge.
        targetVertex - target vertex of the edge.
        Returns:
        The removed edge, or null if no edge removed.

      • getEdgeWeight

        double getEdgeWeight(Vertex sourceVertex,
                     Vertex targetVertex)
        Returns the weight assigned to a given edge. Unweighted graphs return 1.0 (as defined by DEFAULT_EDGE_WEIGHT), allowing weighted-graph algorithms to apply to them when meaningful.
        Parameters:
        sourceVertex - source vertex of the edge.
        targetVertex - target vertex of the edge.
        Returns:
        edge weight

      • setEdgeWeight

        void setEdgeWeight(Vertex sourceVertex,
                   Vertex targetVertex,
                   double weight)
        Assigns a weight to an edge.
        Parameters:
        sourceVertex - source vertex of the edge.
        targetVertex - target vertex of the edge.
        weight - new weight for edge
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the graph does not support weights

      • equals

        boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
        Compares the specified object with this set for equality. Returns true if the given object is also a Graph, the two graphs have the same number of vertices, with the same labels, and the given graph has an edge between each pair of adjacent vertices. This ensures that the equals method works properly across different implementations of the Graph interface.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        o - object to be compared for equality with this graph
        Returns:
        true if the specified object is equal to this graph, false otherwise

      • toString

        java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this, of form:
        Vertices: v1, v2, ... vn
        v1 -> v4
        v2 -> v6
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:

      • visit

        GraphSearchResult visit(SearchType type)
                 throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Performs a visit (of type type) over the current graph. DA IMPLEMENTARE (per pratico 1): solo BFS e DFS_TOT. HINT: si consideri l'implementazione di una visita generica che prenda in input un oggetto "frangia", con frangia diversa a seconda della visita (come visto a lezione).
        Parameters:
        type - the search type.
        Returns:
        a GraphSearchResult representing the result of the visit performed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the visit cannot be performed on the current graph (e.g., a Dijkstra visit on an unweighted graph).

      • isCyclic

        boolean isCyclic()
        Check whether the current graph contains cycles or not.
        Returns:
        true if the current graph contains cycles, false otherwise.

      • isDAG

        boolean isDAG()
        Check whether the current graph is a directed acyclic graph (DAG) or not.
        Returns:
        true if the current graph is a DAG, false otherwise.

      • topologicalSort

        Vertex[] topologicalSort()
        If the current graph is a DAG, it returns a topological sort of this graph.
        Returns:
        a topological sort of this graph.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the current graph is not a DAG.

      • stronglyConnectedComponents

        java.util.Collection<java.util.Collection<Vertex>> stronglyConnectedComponents()
        If the current graph is directed, this method returns the strongly connected components of the graph. Otherwise, the method throws an UnsupportedOperationException.
        Returns:
        a collection of collections of vertices representing the strongly connected components of the graph.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the current graph is not directed.

      • toStringSCC

        java.lang.String toStringSCC()
        Returns a string representing the strongly connected components of the graph. For instance: {{1,2,3},{4,6},{5}}
        Returns:
        a string representing the strongly connected components of the graph.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the current graph is not directed.
